resources.string:
Ingredients：
 	20g Almonds
 	20g Blueberries
 	20g Blackberries
 	20g Mangoes
 Sauce：
 	5g Blueberries
 	5g Strawberry
 	10g Yogurt
 Preparation:
 	1. Dice the mangoes into small pieces, and put the ingredients into a bowl.
 	2. Using a blender, mix the sauce.
 	3. Done! Enjoy the meal.

Material:
 	5 cloves garlic
 	1g salt

Preparation:
 	1. Dice the garlic into small pieces.
 	2. Fried garlic with vege oil, then add lettuce and salt.
 	3. Done! Enjoy your meal.

Material:
 	2 eggs
 	300g diced tomatoes 
 	1g salt

Preparation:
 	1. Scramble eggs in a bowl.
 	2. Fried diced tomatoes for about a minute, then add salt.
 	3. Add eggs, cook until eggs are done.
 	4. Done! Enjoy the meal.

Material:
 	200g diced Broccoli
 	5 cloves garlic
 Sauce:
 	5g oyster
 	0.5g salt
 	5g sesame oil

Preparation:
 	1. Boil the broccoli until fully cooked.
 	2. Drain the broccoli and put into a mixing bowl.
 	3. Add the sauces and mix them well.
 	4. Done! Enjoy the meal.
Includes animal byproducts, including milk and its byproducts
Includes cereal grain plants and legumes (beans, etc.)
Includes meat from all living things not living in the sea
Includes any sea life caught for consumption, including sea plants
Includes any non-cereal and non-legume plant matter used for food
Bird eggs, such as from chickens
Animal milk, such as from cows or goats
Rice grain, including white, brown, etc.
Food prepared from dough and water, usually baked
Stretched and rolled dough with sauces
Pig meat, and meats derived from it (eg: ham, etc.)
Cow meat, and meats derived from it
Chicken meat, and meats derived from it
Meat from any kinds of fish
Kale, and similar green leafy vegetables
The goal of the Green Food Challenge is to help the people of Metro Vancouver learn about greenhouse gas emissions, and work together with simple, easy changes to reduce our carbon footprint.

A carbon footprint is simply a measure of how much an individual\'s carbon dioxide emissions (CO₂e) are in tonnes over a period of time (usually a year). In Metro Vancouver, per the 2015 measurement, our CO₂e per person is around 6 to 8 tonnes per year, adding up to 14.9 million tonnes for the entirety of the Metro Vancouver area! Most experts estimate that, globally, emissions must be reduced to around 2.0 tonnes per person by 2050.
What Does Food Have to Do With It?

People often neglect to mention the impact of food consumption on global CO₂e. In fact, in Metro Vancouver, food contributes more to our carbon footprint than consumables and waste, with 1.5 tonnes of CO₂e per person! This means that food produces nearly 3 million tonnes of CO₂e in Metro Vancouver alone. \n\n Among foods we eat, some foods have a much heavier impact than others. As an example, pork has more than half the CO₂e impact that beef has; likewise, chicken has nearly half the impact that pork has, and lentils have nearly 1/7th the impact of chicken. Some people might be put off from the idea of switching their diet entirely off meat, but as we can see, even switching from beef to chicken can nearly quarter one\'s CO₂e! If the whole city did this, we could reduce the CO₂e levels of Metro Vancouver by nearly 2.3 million tonnes!
So How Does the Green Food Challenge Factor Into This?

The Green Food Challenge aims to create an enjoyable and user friendly app to help people work together to make small changes, so that we as a city can make a big change. 

 First, the app will calculate how much a user's diet produces in CO₂e, and then show how much they, and the community as a whole, could save with simple dietary changes. 

 Throughout the course of the challenge, those participating will be able to track their "green meals" (i.e. diets consisting of either chicken, seafood, or plant-based proteins), and will be able to see the effects of their savings as a community. Additionally, those participating in the challenge will be able to share restaurants with low-carbon meals, supporting local businesses and encouraging others to switch to a low-carbon diet as well. The end goal is to encourage a simple, sustainable diet that will do wonders for creating a lighter carbon footprint.

With a few simple dietary changes, you could save
If everyone in Vancouver made these changes, we could save
